Notes: WEIRD!! Unique morphology, it resembles a little some other spcms already determined as E.salicifolia although the leaves are a little bit larger.  The inflorescence has relatively few flowers (typical of E.salicifolia and not from other spp like E.anugstifolia or coquimbensis).  Also the flowers are relatively large as it is thought to be in E. salicifolia.  NOTE THERE IS A SPCM FROM BOLIVIA-TARIJA (BECK 772, AT L) THAT WAS DETERMINED AS SALICIFOLIA BY SLEUMER, BUT IT HAS SINGLE FLOWERS, LIKE E.MYRTILLOIDES...I PUT IT UNDER MYRTILLOIDES, ALTHOUGH THE LEAVES ARE A BIT DIFFERENT, AND RESEMBLING MORE E.SALICIFOLIA-CORDOBENSIS-COQUIMBENSIS-ANGUSTIFOLIA.  Leaf bases are in general very attenuate, almost not having petiole at all. There are some inflorescences that have fewer flowers...one actually seems to have only one flower! The disk is relatively tall and papillate. Adaxial hairs mainly along midvein and margin.  Margins very ciliolate.  Young leaves very hairy (2) adaxially. Abaxial haris along midvein and margin. Style clearly longer than filaments; anthers 2.37 mm.  Very DRY...DNA?

NOTE: THERE IS JUST ONE MORE SPCM, THE TYPE (AT L) THAT I DID NOT MEASURE AS IT IS VERY FRAGMENTARY, JUST TWO LEAVES AND 2 FLOWERS...INFLORESCENCE WITH SINGLE FLOWERS??  THE LEAVES, HOWEVER, DO RESEMBLE THIS SPCM (VARGAS 9246) FROM TACNA. Almost all inflorescences with just 1 flower but some with up to 3 flowers; it's very likely that some flowers may have fallen off.  The fussion of the syle to the disk seems of the type 1, but I wonder if this is an artifact of the very dry and old state of the specimen. Old but greenish, DNA?
